original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares close lower after eight sessions on profit taking
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka shares close down on Wednesday after profit taking spurred the market, an analyst said.

The main All Share Price Index was down 0.79 percent or 92.25 points to 11,631.97, this is the first time the market closed on red since July 26, while S&P SL20 was up 0.64 percent or 22.17 points to 3,447.96.
“The economy has channeled some stability and some recovery, resulting in buying power for the banking sector and blue chip counters,” an analyst said.

Sri Lanka President Ranil Wickremesinghe has said debt restructuring is matter involving public finances coming under parliament and not courts, and has called opposition groups not to disrupt the process through legal action, a statement said.
“Public finance belongs to parliament,” President Wickremesinghe was quoted as saying at a forum of coconut farmers on Friday.
“This plan has already been approved by parliament. This process will only be halted on the instructions of parliament. We cannot take orders or instructions from anyone else.”
“So, I am telling smaller parties not to create un-necessary problems.”
“There is spread in the market; investors are investing in the capital sector, blue chip companies, banking and diversified financials and tourism counters,” the analyst said.
The market generated a turnover of 1.9 billion rupees, majority of the revenue came in from the banking sector bringing in 509 million rupees, while the yearly average stands at 1.8 billion rupees.
“There is an assumption that earnings reports will be favorable, channeling continuous interest in the market,” an analyst said.
Losers during trade were Ceylinco Insurance, John Keells Holdings, and CT Holdings.
The market saw a net foreign inflow of 279 million rupees, while the yearly net foreign inflow was 5.6 billion rupees. (Colombo/Aug03/20
